Governments: EU agrees to move AI bill proposal to next stage

MEPs have agreed to move the proposed AI Act to the next stage, called the Trilogue, in which EU lawmakers and member states will discuss the final details of the proposal. The proposal includes classifying AI tools according to the level of perceived risk. High-risk tools may not be required to be banned, but those who use them must be transparent about their operations. Companies that deploy generative AI tools, such as ChatGPT or Midjourney, must disclose any copyrighted material used in developing them.

حكومات:الاتحاد الأوروبي يوافق على انتقال مقترح قانون الذكاء الاصطناعي إلى المرحلة التالية

UK Information Commissioner warns against sentiment analysis techniques

The UK Information Commissioner has warned companies against emotional analysis techniques, due to the pseudo-scientific nature of these techniques and their lack of clear basis. He added that companies should stay away from these techniques or face financial penalties. He explained that his warning aims to avoid the harm caused by companies making important decisions based on meaningless data. The Deputy Commissioner stated that these techniques are not supported by science and should not be used to make decisions that are important to people’s lives, but can only be used for entertainment.

Researchers develop AI model to protect civil defense personnel from fire risk

Researchers from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) in the United States, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, and others have developed a deep learning model called FlashNet that can predict the risk of combustible materials igniting seconds before a fire breaks out, based on continuous streams of temperature data in burning buildings. The model was trained on simulated data of more than (41) thousand fires in (17) residential projects in the United States, and the model proved effective with an accuracy of up to (92%). The researchers intend to test the model using real-world data to deploy and use the model.

NATO Releases First AI Strategy

NATO has released its first ever AI Strategy, which aims to define how AI can be applied in defence and security in a safe and ethical manner, and to ensure that standards for the responsible use of AI technologies are in place in line with international law and NATO principles and values. The strategy is based on six key principles: legality, accountability, transparency, reliability, governance and the reduction of bias, enabling appropriate risk assessments to be made before AI applications are adopted. The strategy also addresses the threats posed by the malicious use of AI and how to protect against them, and confirms NATO’s cooperation with international AI standard-setters and engagement with them to help strengthen the coherence of military and civilian standards.

الناتو يُصدر إستراتيجيته الأولى للذكاء الاصطناعي

أصدر حلف شمال الأطلسي (NATO) أول إستراتيجية ذكاء اصطناعي خاصة بالحلف بهدف تحديد كيفية تطبيق الذكاء الاصطناعي في مجالات الدفاع والأمن بطريقة آمنة وأخلاقية، وضمان وجود معايير للاستخدام المسؤول لتقنيات الذكاء الاصطناعي بما يتوافق مع القانون الدولي ومبادئ الحلف وقيمه. وتستند الإستراتيجية على ستة مبادئ رئيسية وهي: الشرعية القانونية والمسؤولية والشفافية والاعتمادية والحوكمة والحد من التحيز، متيحةً بذلك إجراء تقييمات مناسبة للمخاطر قبل اعتماد استخدام تطبيقات الذكاء الاصطناعي. كما تتناول الإستراتيجية التهديدات الناتجة عن الاستخدام الضار للذكاء الاصطناعي وكيفية الحماية منها، وتؤكد تعاون الحلف مع الجهات الدولية المعنية بوضع معايير الذكاء الاصطناعي والعمل معهم للمساعدة في تعزيز ترابط المعايير العسكرية والمدنية.

Chinese company Baidu has unveiled its self-driving car with a detachable steering wheel, which it intends to use to provide taxi services next year. The company seeks to outdo its American counterpart Tesla, which plans to produce a similar car in 2024. Governments: US issues guidance to help companies avoid breaking laws when using AI in recruitment

The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) has issued guidance to help companies avoid violating Title VII of the Civil Rights Act (1964) when using artificial intelligence and algorithmic or machine learning-based software in hiring. The guidance clarifies that Title VII laws apply to companies’ use of AI and similar technologies if the technology is biased against certain groups. The EEOC notes that companies can still be held liable for bias in the AI ​​and algorithmic tools they use even if they are managed by third-party providers.

Ministry of Environment, Water and Agriculture launches a program to monitor and evaluate vegetation cover using artificial intelligence techniques

The Ministry of Environment, Water and Agriculture in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia has launched a program to monitor and evaluate vegetation cover using remote sensing and artificial intelligence technologies, with the aim of studying the reality of vegetation cover areas and contributing to enhancing the objectives of the Saudi Green Initiative and national afforestation projects, in addition to calculating rainfall amounts and vegetation density. The CEO confirmed that the center is interested in developing green spaces in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through afforestation projects and using the latest technologies.

AI predicts 10-year risk of heart attack or stroke from a single X-ray

A team of researchers at the National Cancer Institute in the United States designed and sponsored a randomized trial in which they trained a deep learning model using 147,497 chest x-rays from the Prostate, Lung, Colorectal, and Ovarian Cancer Screening Trial. They tested the model, called CXR-CVD, on an independent cohort of 11,430 patients who had undergone chest x-rays and were eligible for statins. The study found that 1,096 of these patients, or 9.6 percent, experienced a major adverse cardiac event over a median follow-up of 10.3 years. They found a significant association between the risk predicted by the CXR-CVD model and the actual observed major cardiac events.

Studies: Developing an artificial intelligence model to predict the spread of breast cancer

Researchers from King's College of London have developed an artificial intelligence model to predict the spread of breast cancer by analyzing changes in the patient's lymph nodes. The researchers intend to expand the testing of the model to several centers in Europe, and develop an artificial intelligence program that uses the model to help patients prevent the spread of breast cancer.

A study from University College London showed that nine out of ten people want self-driving vehicles to be labeled to distinguish them from human-driven vehicles, after studying a random sample of (4860) British citizens.
